awd_titl_txt: Signal Processing for Passive RF Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project considers passive radio frequency (RF) sensing that employs wireless communication signals as illuminators of opportunities (IOs) to detect, locate, and track objects of interest. Such capabilities are useful for a wide range of applications, e.g., indoor localization, health monitoring, vehicle tracking, and many more. Originally considered as a supplementary technology to active sensing (e.g., radar), passive RF sensing has emerged as a promising alternative that far exceeds the scope of standard radar operations. Passive RF sensing has many advantages over its active counterpart: no dedicated transmitter and RF pollution free; covert operation; order of magnitude cheaper to build, deploy and operate; and the ability to simultaneously access several IOs to obtain multiple views and spatial diversity of the surveillance area. Recent interest in passive RF sensing is further driven by spectrum scarcity and a growing pressure from the wireless sector to release government-held spectrum, including spectrum allocated to active sensing, in order to boost the economy. Given the ubiquity of wireless infrastructure, it is expected that passive RF sensing will be integrated in people's daily life. For example, wireless service providers can offer wireless devices with built-in passive RF sensing functions and make them broadly available to any user. Thus, the associated economical and societal impact of the proposed research is substantial.

Despite the advantages, there are fundamental technical issues that need to be investigated for passive RF sensing. Specifically, unlike active sensing which has a well-established theory for optimum signal processing based on the matched filter (MF), existing passive sensing techniques were introduced largely by imitating the MF, without adequately considering the differences between the two systems. The MF requires knowledge of the transmitted waveform that is unavailable in a passive system due to the non-cooperative nature of the IO. The standard strategy is to replace it with a reference signal, which is a noisy copy of the IO waveform obtained via an antenna steered toward the IO, and cross-correlates (CC) the reference signal with the received signal. The CC detector is not an optimal method. In fact, it is very sensitive to the noise contained in the reference and further deteriorated by the direct-path interference, i.e., the direct transmission from the IO to the passive receiver. To address these issues, this project aims to develop novel signal processing techniques for passive RF sensing by taking into account impairments such as noisy reference, DPI, and multi-path clutter, which are inherent in passive systems. In addition, the project will develop techniques for passive RF sensing involving sensors placed on moving platforms (e.g., unmanned aerial vehicles) to obtain close-up looks of the scene, which is of interest for disaster relief, rural search, and many other applications. A major technical challenge there is to cope with excessive clutter Doppler spread induced by platform motion. Finally, this project also has a significant educational component aimed to provide integrated research experience and training for undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Passive radio frequency (RF) sensing employs ambient wireless communication signals as illuminators of opportunities (IOs) to detect, locate, and track objects of interest. Such capabilities are useful for a wide range of applications, e.g., indoor localization, health monitoring, vehicle tracking, and many more. Passive RF sensing has many advantages over active RF sensing: no dedicated transmitter and RF pollution free; covert operation; order of magnitude cheaper to build, deploy and operate; and the ability to simultaneously access several IOs to obtain multiple views of the surveillance area. Despite the advantages, there are fundamental issues in passive RF sensing. Due to the non-cooperative nature of IO sources, a passive system often employs a cross-correlator (CC) to find targets. The CC cross-correlates the received signal with a reference signal, which is a noisy copy of the IO waveform obtained via a directive antenna steered toward the IO. The CC is very sensitive to the noise in the reference signal. Furthermore, a passive system is limited by the direct-path interference (DPI), i.e., the direct transmission from the IO to a passive receiver, which may severely degrade the sensing performance. This project was aimed to address the above challenging issues and develop novel signal processing techniques that are specifically optimized for passive RF sensing.

The major research outcomes of this project are summarized as follows. First, for passive detection with noisy reference, the PI pursued two different directions by treating the waveform as either deterministic or stochastic quantity, which led to two families of passive detection methods. While the deterministic methods are simpler to implement, the stochastic methods facilitate the exploitation of the temporal correlation of the IO waveform to improve detection performance. These methods were extended to cases with unknown noise characteristics by integrating adaptive estimation techniques for passive detection.

Second, the PI investigated joint interference mitigation and parameter estimation in a general passive sensing environment with noisy reference, DPI, clutter, and multipath. A parametric framework was introduced to estimate the target delay and Doppler frequency, as well as other DPI/clutter parameters, in an iterative fashion. The PI developed both a rigorous expectation-maximization (EM) based estimator and an approximate implementation of the EM estimator. The latter, which leverages fast Fourier transform (FFT) and local interpolation for estimation, is computationally much more efficient than the exact EM estimator and thus suitable for implementation in practical passive sensing systems. The target delay and Doppler estimation methods were further extended to a multi-static sensing scenario with multiple spatially distributed passive sensors to find the location and velocity of the moving target.

Third, when placed on multiple moving platforms such as unmanned aerial vehicles, passive sensors observe excessive Doppler spread in the target and clutter echoes that are difficult to estimate using conventional methods due to limited observations. The PI developed an efficient approach by exploiting spatial and spectral sparsity inherent in the clutter and target signals. Specifically, spatial sparsity allows clutter to be mitigated locally at each sensor without requiring training data. Spectral sparsity transforms the problem of recovering the target signal at different sensors as a group-Lasso problem. Two dedicated solutions were developed, including an exact solution obtained by extending the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) and an approximate but more efficient solution through a matching and thresholding process.

Finally, this project also provided invaluable research experience and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the PI's institution.

Passive RF sensing, which obviates dedicated spectrum allocation by hitchhiking existing wireless signals, has emerged as an attractive RF sensing approach as radio spectrum continues becoming scarcer. Given the ubiquitous wireless infrastructure, passive RF sensing can be integrated in peoples' daily life. For example, wireless service providers can offer wireless devices with built-in passive RF sensing functions and make them broadly available to any user. The associated economical and societal impact of passive is expected to be profound.
